messageBody:
On Wed, 2003-09-17 at 17:03, Vladimir Ritz Bossicard wrote:
> > Never, ever, ever? I can see why the System.out.println() is
> > redundant here, since the assertEquals will provide the actual
> > length of the vector on failure. But generally, when and where
> > are diagnostic messages in tests appropriate? Do you have a problem
> > with System.out.println() or diagnostic messages in tests in general?
>
> System.out.println got lost, assertXYZ don't. If an assert message
> doesn't give you enough information to debug your code, then maybe the
> assert is not doing enough. A least that's what I think.

What about http://apricot.sourceforge.net/ ?

"During their execution, the classes have access to
external ressources (database or network connections...)
via Services and can use the Logger to save useful information."

Vladamir, are you saying you don't need such a Logger any more?

My own preference is to use log4j events in tests so I can
monitor what is going on, which is especially useful when a test
fails. I accept that System.out is rather primitive, but if your
test runner is able to capture the output to this stream and
present it with the test, then it doesn't have to get lost.

I'm interested in this stuff because I'm interested in the process
different programmers choose to adopt when using JUnit. For example,
when you write a failing test you can often get it to pass once you
implement the functionality. Sometimes, however, the test still fails
unexpectedly. That's why tests are so useful, they tell you you've made
a mistake immediately. Programmers who don't write tests would assume
at the point of implementation that they hadn't made a mistake and
continue with the next task.

How do people fix such a failing test? What information do you use to
diagnose and fix it? Or is it always the time to reach for your
debugger?

Malcolm
